.wp-block-audio figcaption{color:#555;font-size:13px;text-align:center}.is-dark-theme .wp-block-audio figcaption{color:hsla(0,0%,100%,.65)}.wp-block-code{border:1px solid #ccc;border-radius:4px;font-family:Menlo,Consolas,monaco,monospace;padding:.8em 1em}.wp-block-embed figcaption{color:#555;font-size:13px;text-align:center}.is-dark-theme .wp-block-embed figcaption{color:hsla(0,0%,100%,.65)}.blocks-gallery-caption{color:#555;font-size:13px;text-align:center}.is-dark-theme .blocks-gallery-caption{color:hsla(0,0%,100%,.65)}.wp-block-image figcaption{color:#555;font-size:13px;text-align:center}.is-dark-theme .wp-block-image figcaption{color:hsla(0,0%,100%,.65)}.wp-block-pullquote{border-top:4px solid;border-bottom:4px solid;margin-bottom:1.75em;color:currentColor}.wp-block-pullquote__citation,.wp-block-pullquote cite,.wp-block-pullquote footer{color:currentColor;text-transform:uppercase;font-size:.8125em;font-style:normal}.wp-block-quote{border-left:.25em solid;margin:0 0 1.75em;padding-left:1em}.wp-block-quote cite,.wp-block-quote footer{color:currentColor;font-size:.8125em;position:relative;font-style:normal}.wp-block-quote.has-text-align-right{border-left:none;border-right:.25em solid;padding-left:0;padding-right:1em}.wp-block-quote.has-text-align-center{border:none;padding-left:0}.wp-block-quote.is-large,.wp-block-quote.is-style-large,.wp-block-quote.is-style-plain{border:none}.wp-block-search .wp-block-search__label{font-weight:700}:where(.wp-block-group.has-background){padding:1.25em 2.375em}.wp-block-separator.has-css-opacity{opacity:.4}.wp-block-separator{border:none;border-bottom:2px solid;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}.wp-block-separator.has-alpha-channel-opacity{opacity:1}.wp-block-separator:not(.is-style-wide):not(.is-style-dots){width:100px}.wp-block-separator.has-background:not(.is-style-dots){border-bottom:none;height:1px}.wp-block-separator.has-background:not(.is-style-wide):not(.is-style-dots){height:2px}.wp-block-table thead{border-bottom:3px solid}.wp-block-table tfoot{border-top:3px solid}.wp-block-table td,.wp-block-table th{padding:.5em;border:1px solid;word-break:normal}.wp-block-table figcaption{color:#555;font-size:13px;text-align:center}.is-dark-theme .wp-block-table figcaption{color:hsla(0,0%,100%,.65)}.wp-block-video figcaption{color:#555;font-size:13px;text-align:center}.is-dark-theme .wp-block-video figcaption{color:hsla(0,0%,100%,.65)}.wp-block-template-part.has-background{padding:1.25em 2.375em;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0}
</style>

<article id="post-1228" class="post-1228 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-plugin tag-wordpress entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/readme-md-plugin-on-wordpress-org/">Using readme.md for a plugin on WordPress.org</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>Did you know that a plugin hosted on the WordPress.org Plugin Directory can use a readme.md markdown file instead of readme.txt? If you manage your plugin on GitHub or GitLab and use a readme.md file there’s no need to maintain or generate a separate readme.txt file — just send the readme.md file straight to wordpress.org.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">
		<span class="posted-on">Published <time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2021-01-20T19:04:24+00:00">20 January 2021</time></span><div class="post-taxonomies"><span class="cat-links">Categorised as <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/category/default/" rel="category tag">Default</a> </span><span class="tags-links">Tagged <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/plugin/" rel="tag">Plugin</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/wordpress/" rel="tag">WordPress</a></span></div>	</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->
</article><!-- #post-${ID} -->

<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/wordpress-developer-tools/">WordPress Developer Tools</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

<article id="post-1041" class="post-1041 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-projects entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/coding-projects-november-2019/">Coding Projects: November 2019</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>At any point in time I usually have a few coding projects on the go. Over the last two years I’ve made a conscious effort to focus on a few projects instead of trying to do everything, so I don’t spread myself too thinly. Here’s a list of projects I’m working on currently.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">
		<span class="posted-on">Published <time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2019-11-08T21:33:20+00:00">8 November 2019</time></span><div class="post-taxonomies"><span class="cat-links">Categorised as <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/category/default/" rel="category tag">Default</a> </span><span class="tags-links">Tagged <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/projects/" rel="tag">Projects</a></span></div>	</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->

<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/wordpress-hook-autocompletion-for-vs-code/">WordPress Hook Autocompletion for VS Code</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>I’ve published a VS Code extension which autocompletes WordPress action and filter names and the corresponding callback function. Check out the extension here on the VS Code Marketplace. It’s new and this is my first VS Code extension so it needs some more work. I’ll be improving it over time but I hope you find… <a class="more-link" href="https://johnblackbourn.com/wordpress-hook-autocompletion-for-vs-code/">Continue reading <span class="screen-reader-text">WordPress Hook Autocompletion for VS Code</span></a></p>

<article id="post-1010" class="post-1010 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-the-web entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/the-unprofessional-web/">The Unprofessional Web</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>You may have heard some news over the last few days about obfuscated and malicious code allegedly being found within a WordPress plugin published by a theme shop called pipdig. Jem Turner covered it here and Wordfence Security covered it here, although the latter chose to only use the word “peculiar” as I suspect they’ve… <a class="more-link" href="https://johnblackbourn.com/the-unprofessional-web/">Continue reading <span class="screen-reader-text">The Unprofessional Web</span></a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">

<article id="post-982" class="post-982 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-plugin tag-wordpress entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/user-switching-ten/">Brief Thoughts on a Ten Year Old WordPress Plugin</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>Today my User Switching plugin for WordPress turns ten years old. Its active user base passed 100,000 last year which I think classifies it as moderately popular. For a plugin that’s primarily developer-oriented that’s a good number.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">
		<span class="posted-on">Published <time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2019-03-05T10:14:07+00:00">5 March 2019</time></span><div class="post-taxonomies"><span class="cat-links">Categorised as <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/category/default/" rel="category tag">Default</a> </span><span class="tags-links">Tagged <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/plugin/" rel="tag">Plugin</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/wordpress/" rel="tag">WordPress</a></span></div>	</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->
</article><!-- #post-${ID} -->

		<p>Last updated: January 2020 I’ve previously written about my Sublime Text packages, but I’ve since switched to the excellent VS Code editor. If you’ve already disregarded this editor based on the Visual Studio prefix in its name, please don’t. There really is no relation to Visual Studio, and I suspect that the marketing team at… <a class="more-link" href="https://johnblackbourn.com/my-code-extensions/">Continue reading <span class="screen-reader-text">My Code Extensions</span></a></p>

<article id="post-884" class="post-884 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-gutenberg tag-wordpress entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/gutenberg-block-template-part/">Rendering Dynamic Gutenberg Blocks in Theme Template Parts</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>Gutenberg is an ambitious project that aims to completely overhaul the experience of writing content in WordPress. One of the problems you’ll soon run into when building a block for Gutenberg is that as a block becomes more complex, storing its complete output statically becomes undesirable. If a block contains several fields or its output… <a class="more-link" href="https://johnblackbourn.com/gutenberg-block-template-part/">Continue reading <span class="screen-reader-text">Rendering Dynamic Gutenberg Blocks in Theme Template Parts</span></a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">
		<span class="posted-on">Published <time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2018-02-01T11:46:38+00:00">1 February 2018</time></span><div class="post-taxonomies"><span class="cat-links">Categorised as <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/category/default/" rel="category tag">Default</a> </span><span class="tags-links">Tagged <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/gutenberg/" rel="tag">Gutenberg</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/wordpress/" rel="tag">WordPress</a></span></div>	</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->
</article><!-- #post-${ID} -->

<article id="post-835" class="post-835 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-developers tag-wordpress entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/wordpress-email-documentation/">Documentation for Emails Sent by WordPress</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>Ever wondered about situations where WordPress sends an email? I documented them all & how to filter or disable them. The document lists every situation where WordPress sends an email, along with how to filter or disable each email.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">
		<span class="posted-on">Published <time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2017-09-27T17:03:38+01:00">27 September 2017</time></span><div class="post-taxonomies"><span class="cat-links">Categorised as <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/category/default/" rel="category tag">Default</a> </span><span class="tags-links">Tagged <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/developers/" rel="tag">Developers</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/wordpress/" rel="tag">WordPress</a></span></div>	</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->

<article id="post-792" class="post-792 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-default tag-ci tag-testing tag-travis tag-wordpress entry">

	
<header class="entry-header">
	<h2 class="entry-title default-max-width"><a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/reducing-travis-ci-build-times-for-wordpress-projects/">Reducing Travis CI Build Times for WordPress Projects</a></h2></header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>Recently I’ve been working to reduce the Travis CI build times of not only WordPress core, but also the WordPress plugins and projects that I maintain. The following patterns and tips will help you speed up your build times. Comments welcome!</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-footer default-max-width">
		<span class="posted-on">Published <time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2017-05-27T13:56:17+01:00">27 May 2017</time></span><div class="post-taxonomies"><span class="cat-links">Categorised as <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/category/default/" rel="category tag">Default</a> </span><span class="tags-links">Tagged <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/ci/" rel="tag">CI</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/testing/" rel="tag">Testing</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/travis/" rel="tag">Travis</a>, <a href="https://johnblackbourn.com/tag/wordpress/" rel="tag">WordPress</a></span></div>	</footer><!-- .entry-footer -->
</article><!-- #post-${ID} -->
